solution.text:
For the first, adiabatic process:
Net work done (W) = _{j}_ J
Since it's an adiabatic process:
\(\Delta Q = 0 \implies \Delta W = -\;_{j}_\) J (Since the work is done on the system)

From the First Law of Thermodynamics: \(\Delta Q = \Delta U + \Delta W\)
\(\implies \Delta U = \Delta Q - \Delta W = - (- _{j}_) = _{j}_ \;J\)

In the second scenario the change in internal energy is the same since the state (B) is the same and the systems are identical.

The net heat absorbed \((\Delta Q)\) = _{k}_ J
Therefore, \(\Delta W = \Delta Q - \Delta U\)\(\implies \Delta W = _{k}_ - _{j}_\)
\(\implies \Delta W = _{{k - j}}_\) Joules

content.text: A system of Hydrogen gas is transformed adiabatically from an equilibrium state A to another equilibrium state B, requiring _{j}_ J of work to be done on the system. An identical system is taken from state A to B via a different process in which the net heat absorbed by the system is _{k}_ J. What is the work done by the system on the surroundings in the latter case ?
